story:
I have no great pitch or fancy words to get you to help me.  The facts are simple.  I am the middle child in a home with 4 other children and my parents work hard but funding a pilgrimage to Rome just is not in their budget.  I am looking to continue and strengthen my faith, discover and learn on my trip to Rome.  I am hoping for $600, which would help so much.  Overall, I need to come up with $2500 plus spending money. Please consider helping me on my pilgrimage, even if it's just $2. 

Thank you for taking the time to check out my campaign! 

*In the gallery of picture, at the bottom is a link to the church flyer There is more details about where we will be going and what we will be learning/experiencing.

story:
FIRST OFF This is a suprise, Mike and Erika don't know about this and please friends and family, don't tell them.

Let me tell you about them, Mike and Erika are the definition of LOVE. They have been together since high school, 15 years later they're 30 years old and still standing strong. They have been engaged for years and now it's time we help them be able to afford their dream wedding. I've never known a love as great as the one they share. One with the ability to move everyone and everything around them. Since I was a little girl (now 24)  I've watch their love grow and grow. Over the years they have only become stronger. I'm envious of a love like the one they have and I only hope one day I will find it too. MIKE AND ERIKA have made me a believer. And to those of you who know them, I'm sure they have made you one too. And to those of you who don't trust me when I say this is THAT FAIRY-TALE TYPE LOVE.

Now about me, my name is Briana. I'm the sister of the I hope soon to be "Groom."
I also consider Erika, my brothers fiance' my sister.  I wasn't blessed to have a sister but Erika did a great job filling in. I've know her for about 15 years and we are extremely close. She's an amazing woman and recently my niece Taliyah told my mom that Erika is always looking at wedding dresses and talking about the perfect wedding. Taliyah also said she hopes she will be able to be the flower girl and hopes that she doesn't grow to big by the time they get married. She said she doesn't know why her dad gave her mom a ring but there was no "ball." She's at that age where she's really into princesses and princes and happily ever after. I don't want her to grow up and think those things are only for story-telling. Let's show her fairy tales do exist and let's help her and my two nephews be a part of one! Happily ever after can come true and I want to gather everyone I possibly can to make sure it does! Today I asked my brother "why haven't you gotten married, you've been engaged for years?" His response was "she wants a big wedding, I want to make that happen but I can't afford it yet. Not with all my medical bills." That broke my heart. If I only I were rich, I thought...But then I came up with a better idea, I don't have to sit around and wish I was rich enough to help them. I can take action, this is for LOVE, help be a part of making this fairy tale ending come true! You don't have to know my brother Mike or Erika, support LOVE. True love is so rare, help be apart of it. They have showed me that true love really can conquer all. Mike and Erika, you've made me and so many around you a believer!

I know not everyone can help with money, but please SHARE THIS. SHARING WILL HELP IN SO MANY MORE WAYS THEN YOU CAN THINK...Hey maybe if were lucky

David Tutera (the tv show wedding planner) will see this and want to help.


HERE's to DREAMING BIG.


Love you Mike And Erika.


Also you can donate whatever you like $1, $5, $10 click the CONTRIBUTE button you don't have to donate the set limits!

story:
My name is Whitney Michele Davis and I am a senior at New Technology High School. I am a loving, kind and passionate young woman who dreams of making a positive contribution to the world through teaching. As I prepare to enter college this fall, I must first complete the University of California’s entrance requirements, which involve having completed 2 years of a foreign language. I have completed 1 year of Spanish, but am still in need of a 2nd year. That is where you come in.

This June, I will be traveling to Salamanca, Spain for 3 weeks with students from the Napa Valley College to study Spanish at the Pontifical University. I will be studying Spanish 4 hours a day, 5 days a week at the University, where I hope to further my understanding of the language, as well as develop an ability to effectively communicate with others while speaking it.

By attending this study-abroad trip, I will not only be able to receive the credit I need in order to attend college this fall, but I will have the opportunity to  participate in a spiritual, emotional and incredibly educational experience. As I pursue my dream of becoming a teacher, it is my hope that I will be able to offer my students the memories of my personal experiences as I encourage them to embark upon their own. Your financial support will enable this dream to become a reality.

I need your help to raise $3,000. This sum will cover the entire cost of the trip, including food, homestay accommodations, airfare, and land travel. Your financial support will not go unnoticed: for your $25.00 donation, I will recognize you in my online blog that I will update while on the trip. For your $50.00 donation,  you will be recognized in a follow-up article that I hope to publish in the local newspaper.

I am unable to articulate in words how excited I am to be a part of this trip, and to have the opportunity to study aboard in Spain. I am so grateful for your support, and look forward to sharing my adventure with you!

Sincerely,

Whitney Michele Davis

story:
Short Summary

For much of my teenage and young adult years I took a wide and wayward path. I lived for myself and that's all I cared about. That all changed in 2006 when I lost my mother to Melanoma. I vowed then to retake my life and direct it towards some kind of redemption. A purpose. A legacy. Something I can give or do that would provide sustenance or positive influence to my family and those I leave behind. It has been an uphill struggle to repair over a decade of damage done and I've come so far though I have reached a plateau. I can go no farther in my (current) career in computer based technologies without earning the certificates that prove I am capable, and trained. Unable to provide anything proper for my child and family without robbing from one bill to cover the rest, and a promise made long ago to never stop pushing for the many instead of the one, I have decided to seek help from friends, family, and heck even a stranger or two to get the ball rolling. Instead of initially taking the long road through 4+ years in college (not to mention the $10K's), I have found a training and certification course that can be completed in 70 hours, a jump start for continuing my education in the future. For, just a couple of dollars from many sources keeps the train moving towards a better life for all in my life whom I have owed so much.

What We Need & What You Get

I am seeking $2000 to enroll in the CompTIA A+ 70 hour course at CPCC.

I plan to tithe 10% of any money raised with the remainder going straight to supplies, books, and the course itself. If by some chance I do not reach the goal as stated I plan to take every "extra" penny I can earn while currently employed in the field until I have enough to enroll. My biggest downfall is the course begins in September and I already live paycheck to paycheck making ends meet.

The only thing I can offer in return at this point is a guaranteed completion at the top of the class and free computer assistance to anyone who believes in me enough to donate.

The Impact

As I am already employed working in the field I have many avenues for advancement with my certs in hand. I envision the ability to become more of who I long to be with every step. This one step will literally double my hourly wage before the end of this year.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you feel lead to do so, please forward and share this with anyone you think may have a dollar, or two, to spare.

story:
The premise of West LA Burrito Project is simple: every other week we meet, cook and pass out hearty burritos to the homeless.

Every other Monday, we meet at Stoner Park Rec Center at 6:30. We cook and assemble the burritos while we chat and then we all head to the Santa Monica Promenade to pass them out. We usually finish up before 9:00.

Last year's fundraisers and private donations brought in over $1,600!  That was enough to fund our project for a whole year, awesome. Help us keep it going one more year through your contributions.

Every dollar of your donations will go to purchasing groceries, I'll cover all of the fundraising fees to ensure it.


Thanks,

Eileen

story:
These children gave me in two months what I know I cannot return in a hundred lives.

I've been to India during last summer. Many times they asked me why. Why. Probably because I was kind of broken, in the naive way only a 20 years old can be. I thought that I had to leave to lose and find myself. That's so cheap, I know. What I didn't know is that I was already lost, somehow. Everything that I strongly believed it was important and all drama in life actually didn't matter. Not when I faced what those children had suffered. And, still, they smile.

I'm not going to tell you the whole story, it's not that interesting. 

But I was thinking of you. Of us all. I promised the boys of Dayavu orphanage that I would be back with a present for them and for their home.

I used to live there, in Tamil Nadu, with one euro per day, including food and sleeping, the bus, internet point, candies. What for us might be almost nothing, in India was enough. So I don't want Christmas presents this year. They don't have money for the slippers. I saved and worked to buy a new flight ticket. But I can't. I have to keep the promise.

Maybe if we get together in this, we can do something important. I'm not telling you that we'll change their lives, that would be a lie. But it could be Christmas for them, their very first.

If there's something I learned there is that we're not going to change the world. But we can change the world for one person. And if we get together, why not for twenty children?


I apologize for this frightening english and I thank you. Thanks

story:
FSH Muscular Dystrophy has always been a part of my life. As awkward and clumsy as I was as a child, I somehow managed to live a pretty normal life.  Even though FSHMD is progressive, I always assumed that it would somehow skip me and just let me enjoy life without losing the function of my facial muscles, arms and legs.  I have been very fortunate that the progression was slow early on.  But, over the last five years, this disease has gone into overdrive causing me to be unable to walk without assistance.  I went from holding onto walls for support to holding on to the arms of people near me, to using a walker/rollator, to a manual wheelchair to now using a powerchair most of the time.I am grateful that I can still stand and use my rollator for a short time, but become exhausted at the simplest of tasks.

I was denied disability assistance because I don't have enough work credits in the system.  Being in limbo, I have used any and all savings I had acquired over the years.  I am in need of a wheelchair accessible van so I can remain independent for as long as possible.  A van would allow me to do basic everyday things such as grocery shopping, doctor's appointments, etc. I also hope that it will allow me to seek employment. Without a van, I would have to rely on a caregiver to assist me with any outings. 

Most people are not aware of the costs involved when trying to purchase modified equipment and vans.  On top of the regular purchase price of a van, modifications (at a minimum) run around $20,000-30,000.  That is a chunk of change even for an able-bodied full time worker.   I have found a used van that is fully equipped (I would only have to add a drivers seat that will rise and swivel so I can transfer from powerchair to driver's seat) for a cost of $24,800.  My hope is that I can raise $6000 to cover a down payment, new swivel driver's seat, license tags and insurance.

It is very difficult to have to ask for help, but I am at a point in my life where I have to rely on the help of friends and family so I can remain as independent as possible. Giving up is not an option and trying to live as normally as possible is a daily fight.  I ask that you please consider making a donation to help me keep fighting.  The only thing I have in return is my never ending gratefulness that you helped me remain strong and independent.

story:
OUR PRODUCT

Correct Me If I’m Wrong™ is a new twist on dry erase activity games that will change the way "write and wipe" activities are played. We are introducing Flip 'n' Check™. It is a special system invented by the famous toy and game inventor, Dr. Wexler. Once a game is completed, the answers are revealed when the activity sheet is flipped over. The answers line up with the players' answers and mistakes are easily wiped away. The system also ensures that there is only one solution for every activity. Simply put, Flip 'n' Check™ allows children to check their own work immediately after finishing an activity sheet. Because the activity sheets are not written on directly, they can be passed on from one child to another as brand new, and therefore any number of children can play. Not only does Correct Me If I’m Wrong™ consist of mazes, connect the dots, word searches, crosswords and classic, two-player paper-and-pencil games, it also has "Story Time", "Three of a Kind", and "How Many?". Every activity is beautifully designed and carefully conceived for age appropriateness. The games are suitable for children ages 5 and up.

 

TESTING

We conducted various focus groups to evaluate our product's age appropriateness, usability, durability, educational value and fun factor. The first round of testing began with our own team, friends and family members and we found that the adults loved the concept and the fun and education it provided. Next, we invited a handful of NYC elementary school teachers to try our product and comment on its age appropriateness and educational value. Finally, we took our rough prototypes to a handful of NYC elementary school classrooms, an after-school program and a summer camp. We found that the children thoroughly loved playing with our activity games! Their enthusiasm for our prototype, which didn’t even contain final artwork or packaging, can only mean they will be more than pleased with our final product.


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

The not-for-profit organization, Teen Entrepreneur Boot Camp is the program responsible for this program that gives teens a hands-on experience with entrepreneurship through the process of launching a real game or toy into the marketplace. All profits from the sales of the game will go back into supporting similar programs like this one. We are about to release our first product,Correct Me If I’m Wrong™, thanks to the help of many professionals who donated their time, advice and pro bono services. Dr. Wexler not only donated his invention to our company, but also loaned us the money to hire a professional graphic artist to create the artwork for our game. We received pro bono services from a highly regarded law firm to obtain trademarks and copyrights for our product and from a public relations firm, services to build our website. In addition, we received advice from toy store owners and managers, sales representatives, lawyers, and marketing executives and received special permission to attend the 2011 and 2012 International Toy Fair. (Normally, no one under 18 is allowed to attend.)

We are turning to Indiegogo to cover our final costs--manufacturing, toy testing, insurance, distribution, and marketing. Specifically, marketing includes maintenance of social media outlets, and distribution includes e-store management. Your donation would not only help complete our goal to sell our first toy, but also help to lay the foundation for future programs like this one.

 

PEOPLE WHO HAVE HELPED US

We are very lucky to have met the following professionals who shared their expertise with us to help with our business planning process:

1. Samantha Martin- Media Maison Public Relations Firm

2. Ameena Meer - CEO/Creative Director, Creative Take-Out

3. Karen Barwick - NYC Toy Store Owner, Boomerang Toys

4. Marian Bossard - VP, Meetings & Events, Toy Industry Association

    * Granted us entrance to the International Toy Fair in NYC.

5. Adrienne Appell - PR Specialist, Toy Industry Association

6. Murray Bass - Manufacturers Representative (sells to Toys R’ Us)

7. Nadine Flynn - Trademark & Copyright Lawyer, Colgate - Palmolive

7. Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft LLP

     *Pro bono work obtaining trademarks and copyrights.

8. Julian Leone , Jason Arena- Goldman Sachs

    * Asst'd in projecting start-up costs and revenue.

9. David Sanborn - FAO Schwarz

10. Max Garcia - Buyer for Whole Foods Kids Products

    * Offered to review our product and introduce us to national buyer.

11. Stu Pollack - Sales Representative

12. Marvin Posner - Former marketing and sales executive, Kenner Toys

13. Ester Du Von - Kids Empowerment Academy

    * Coached students on product presentation.

14. Michele Luzio, Esq.

All the professionals listed above have expressed enthusiasm and confidence with regard to the success of our program.

 

WHO WE ARE

Since 2008, Teen Entrepreneur Boot Camp has run numerous after-school and summer sessions in NYC on entrepreneurship for teens and has been featured in news articles in The Daily News, The Downtown Express, and The Battery Park City Broadsheet, as well as TV news reports on Fox 5 Good Day New York, NY1 and Fuji TV Network.

http://www.teenentrepreneurbootcamp.org 

http://www.toysbyteens.com

Dr. Howard Wexler has invented and licensed over 120 toys and games during his extensive career. Besides donating the actual idea for the game, Correct Me If I'm Wrong, he guided the students in developing it.

The students participating in this project are from the highly regarded Stuyvesant High School located in lower Manhattan. http://www.stuy.edu

Dr. Wexler not only donated his invention to our company, but also loaned us the money to hire a professional graphic artist to create the artwork for our game. We received pro bono services from a highly regarded law firm to obtain trademarks and copyrights for our product and from a public relations firm, services to build our website. In addition, we received advice from toy store owners and managers, sales representatives, lawyers, and marketing executives and received special permission to attend the 2011 and 2012 International Toy Fair. (Normally, no one under 18 is allowed to attend.)
We are turning to Indiegogo to cover our final costs--manufacturing, toy testing, insurance, distribution, and marketing. Specifically, marketing includes maintenance of social media outlets, and distribution includes e-store management. Your donation would not only help complete our goal to sell our first toy, but also help to lay the foundation for future programs like this one.
 
PEOPLE WHO HAVE HELPED US 
We are very lucky to have met the following professionals who shared their expertise with us to help with our business planning process:
1. Samantha Martin- Media Maison Public Relations Firm
2. Ameena Meer - CEO/Creative Director, Creative Take-Out
3. Karen Barwick - NYC Toy Store Owner, Boomerang Toys
4. Marian Bossard - VP, Meetings & Events, Toy Industry Association
    * Granted us entrance to the International Toy Fair in NYC.
5. Adrienne Appell - PR Specialist, Toy Industry Association
6. Murray Bass - Manufacturers Representative (sells to Toys R’ Us)
7. Nadine Flynn - Trademark & Copyright Lawyer, Colgate - Palmolive
7. Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft LLP
     *Pro bono work obtaining trademarks and copyrights.
8. Julian Leone , Jason Arena- Goldman Sachs
    * Asst'd in projecting start-up costs and revenue.
9. David Sanborn - FAO Schwarz
10. Max Garcia - Buyer for Whole Foods Kids Products
    * Offered to review our product and introduce us to national buyer.
11. Stu Pollack - Sales Representative
12. Marvin Posner - Former marketing and sales executive, Kenner Toys
13. Ester Du Von - Kids Empowerment Academy
    * Coached students on product presentation.
14. Michele Luzio, Esq.
All the professionals listed above have expressed enthusiasm and confidence with regard to the success of our program.
 
WHO WE ARE 
Since 2008, Teen Entrepreneur Boot Camp has run numerous after-school and summer sessions in NYC on entrepreneurship for teens and has been featured in news articles in The Daily News, The Downtown Express, and The Battery Park City Broadsheet, as well as TV news reports on Fox 5 Good Day New York, NY1 and Fuji TV Network.
http://www.teenentrepreneurbootcamp.org 
http://www.toysbyteens.com
Dr. Howard Wexler has invented and licensed over 120 toys and games during his extensive career. Besides donating the actual idea for the game, Correct Me If I'm Wrong, he guided the students in developing it.
The students participating in this project are from the highly regarded Stuyvesant High School located in lower Manhattan. http://www.stuy.edu

story:
Our Story

My name is Chris Aviles. I teach English at Barnegat High School in Barnegat, New Jersey. This is not my Campaign. This is my students' Campaign.

This year, I asked my students what skills they think they would need to be successful in the 21st century. They said things like perseverance, collaboration, hustle, being personable, being tech savvy, and a great communicator.

I then had them research how 21st century companies were fostering those skills. When the first student did a GIS for Google work environment I thought his head was going to explode. Soon, all of my kids were looking up great workspaces. At first they were excited, but then they got mad.

"We could do so much more," they said.

They wondered, "Why can't we learn in places like that?"

I felt bad. I didn't have a good answer for them.

Instead of becoming defeated, they were motivated. My students made it clear that they wanted to learn in places like that; they wanted to learn in a 21st century workspace and they were going to make it happen.

I use Project and Problem-based Learning in my classroom, so I was excited to see students using the skills we've worked on all year and starting to organize themselves and brainstorm solutions. I sat back and watched as 75 kids, spread across three periods, focused their energy to achieve one goal: getting more out of their classroom. I was thrilled! My students identified a problem, but instead of giving in to teenage-apathy, they decided to do something about it. After much debate and planning they decided crowd-funding was the answer.

My students have set out to raise $6,500 to improve the technology in their classroom and replace their old, uncomfortable desks (the ones we all hated sitting in), and turn their classroom walls into a living canvas for students to decorate every year. 

My kids worked hard. The video you see, the pricing, rewards you'll receive, and everything else was all them. They wanted to do something great. I just got out of their way.

And yes, my kids really are this great.

Our Goal

How much and what we get depends on what we raise; my average class size is thirty. We totally don't expect to raise that much money, so we are shooting for just half.  My kids hope the classes that come after them will want to follow in their footsteps and help raise the money until the classroom is complete. They want to start a tradition.

My students made a wishlist:

  • ~15 Learn2 desks from KI Furniture (They have been working close with the kids and have put together a great deal for us! They even donated a desk!) 

  • ~2 Pub-style tables, so students can stand while they learn (Thinking IKEA tables for this)
  • ~10 Chromebooks.
  • Paint, brackets, hangers, etc. to turn the walls into a living canvas for student artwork and projects.

    The Impact

    This has been a much longer journey than my students or I ever imagined.

    They've overcome many obstacles that I've chronicled here, but I think the biggest impact of all has been the realization that being apathetic isn't cool. They've identified a problem and formulated a solution. Even if we fail, they've told me they've learned a lot. The journey is where the learning happens.

      Risks & Challenges

      My students know they will face challenges:

      Is $6,500 enough?

      What if we only raise a little bit, or nothing at all?

      How can we get the word out? 

      Will we really have to come during the summer to help setup the classroom and get rewards out on time? Like seriously, will we?!

      However, I think they've overcome the two biggest challenges already. 1) They've made a Campaign! They put themselves out there. They put their full effort and passion into getting this Campaign off the ground knowing that failure is a very real possibility and (2) they've realized they will never get to learn in this classroom, since they will be promoted to the next grade by the time the classroom is done, but want to do it anyway. Their 21st century classroom is no longer for them, but for the students who come after them. This classroom is a gift.

      Even if my students fail, I am still proud of them and happy to see they have put the Project and Problem-based Learning we've been doing all year to good, real-world use. What more could a teacher ask for?

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't or don't want to donate, it's cool. Even if you just spread the word and make some noise, we would appreciate it!

story:
Eileen's Story

We first met Eileen a couple years ago when she was a high school freshman.  During a time when The Supply was just starting off and in need of financial assistance, Eileen stepped up and delivered us a check for $200.  We were blown away by her generosity and promised her that this seed would be planted and would grow to something amazing. 

She ended up starting a chapter at her high school, where she became one of our most active high school fundraisers and supporters.  She led her school to raise over $2,000 last year and because of her avid support, we asked her to speak at our 2012 gala event in NYC.  Her passion and generosity inspired the older audience to give.

Eileen is approaching her senior year now.  A week ago, Eileen just came back from the Lenana slums as part of this year's High School Immersion Program.  After spending time in the community, living and breathing The Supply's work, her passion was solidified. She emailed us wanting to do more.

Eileen's Call to Action

Eileen spent this summer working hard to save money.  She thought of all the things she could do and the places she could go with the hard-earned money.  However, with the $3,000 she has saved, she wants to challenge and inspire others to take up a call to action.  She is matching dollar-for-dollar up to $3,000. That's right, $3,000.  

How it Works

Simple! If you donate $1, it's equivalent to $2.  If you donate $100, it's $200!  A generous high school senior is matching your funds dollar for dollar from money earned from her summer job! Crazy!

Where the Funds will be Going

50% of the funds will be going to a more secure roof for the Jumba Lenana Academy (secondary school in Lenana) and 50% of the funds will be going to our second secondary school build in the Matopeni slums (150,000 residents and no community secondary school).  

The Impact

Eileen's $200 donation has grown exponentially in the past two years.  For The Supply, we have been able to grow as an organization and do impactful work out in the slums of Nairobi.  Through your donation, we will be able to continue to educate and empower the next wave of local leaders in these urban slums.  On the other hand, Eileen, who has been along with us through the entire process, is now able to stretch her $200 donation to a $3,000 committment.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Shoot a tweet about this campaign! @thesupply Hashtag #EileensStory

Join our email listserve and share about The Supply at http://thesupply.org/share/

story:
Hi people out there! I’m Steven Davis and this is my son Matthew, 16years old. Handsome young man! Help him get his first car. Wait, wait, wait, keep reading!! It will brighten your day to know all is not lost on our next generation, and might even make you a bit proud. I’ve tried to teach Matt, and all my children, the value of hard work, responsibility, and earning what you get. Something that is not very common in this instant gratification and self entitled society of today. He has learned these ethics better than I could have ever hoped! 


Matthew got his first job this year. I got him enrolled in a program that teaches young people good work ethics and he started working for an apartment complex. He has spent five days a week, 8 hours a day, all summer long getting up at 6 A.M. to go to work. He works outside in more than 100 degree heat mowing, painting, and moving stuff. Basically, stuff no one else wants to do. He even helped build a playground for the children in the complex last week. The man that installs them saw him working and asked if he could help him put in the new playground after his regular job. Matthew worked two jobs at this point. On the last day of the playground job I dropped him off early in the morning and there was a pile of wood chips taller than the slide. We of course laughed and I kidded him about the size of the pile, and told him good luck. To my amazement, when I came back at 3:00 in the afternoon, the pile was gone and there was Matt with a rake finishing leveling the wood chips in a 100’x 50’by one foot deep playground basin. It was over 105 degrees that day. His boss ,who travels all over the country installing custom playgrounds, told me he had never had a harder worker and ask if Matt could work for him the next summer and offered him a job when he graduates. This is just one example of how hard Matt has worked for what he wants. It’s what made me realize, what kid these days does this, what kid really works that hard, and what I had to do for him. Matthew has worked harder than most adults I know. Still, he does his chores at home with a laugh and a smile. He has never complained! Never has a bad attitude even when he is worn out. Most evenings he falls asleep at 8 or 9 P.M. He has saved more than 1000$ on his own, and would be happy with anything he gets. He has earned something to be proud of, and more than we can give.


I’m asking all of you out there for help. All the people that read this and agree it’s awesome to see a kid give whole heartedly for what he wants to acheive. All the people that believe that it’s who you are and what you do that get you what you want and where you want to go in life. I'm asking all of you to donate to Matt’s car fund.


My wife and I are both nurses and are going to contribute as much as we can to his car fund. We are limited, though, because we are on a fixed budget. I have always told Matt that if he works hard he can have and do anything. Good old American way right? He has stayed true to his side of the deal, and I am so proud of him. I would love to see him get what he has earned. Help me to cement the value of hard work in his mind. It's a lesson that will carry with him all his life!! 


I understand not all can donate, that’s ok. Send him a prayer, or a GOOD JOB BUD!! All is welcomed and appreciated.


Thank you, 

A proud and honored Father

story:
Short Summary

I teach 6th and 7th grade Science at a Title 1 (Economically Disadvantaged) Middle school in Fort Worth, Texas. Most of my students come to me believing they will never be able to break out of the "hood." By the time they leave me, most are planning to go on to college, many planning to pursue careers in science. Unfortunately, my district has not provided any supplies for experiments in three years.  I spend an average of $2,000 out of pocket so that my students can actually experience science and not just read about it. In order to afford this, I maintain a second job as a wedding DJ on weekends. I actually use this activity as well; I dj our school dances (free of charge, of course).

This year is going to be an exciting year for my students. Due to our budget issues, many of our investigations are outdoors, environment-based. There is a park and creek two blocks from our school. Last year, students identified coliform in the water. Coliform is a bacteria found in mammal feces. By working upstream with testing, students were able to identify two sources of the coliform, and wrote letters to the Mayor. As a result, the parks department is going to add a wetlands area to filter the creek water, which feeds into the Trinity River, the source of our drinking water.

After a meeting with the parks department, we have agreed that the students are going to help with this remodel project, providing labor and working side by side with Master Naturalists and the Parks Environmental department, freeing up funds for additional park amenities. My students are going to monitor water quality above and below the wetlands to determine the effecctiveness of this project. Students will also conduct periodic park cleanups.

I have taken a group of students many consider throw aways, and instilled them with a desire to learn and a desire to make a difference in their community. When my students wrote the Mayor, they were telling her, "This is our community. We want to be involved." These were their words!

What We Need & What You Get

Our school has 24 computers to serve 550 students, making research for projects almost impossible. Even when I can schedule time in the computer lab, each of my classes has 30+ students, forcing students to double up on computers. Most of my students do not have computers at home, so all work has to be done at school. Our wish list includes:

30 netbooks to conduct research in the classroom.

10 digital cameras to record project progress, prepare science fair projects, and for field investigations.

10 Discover Scopes. These are field microscopes which will help students monitor health of the wetlands area.

All items will be used weekly throughout the year, and will be shared with other classes when we are not using them. All 550 students in the school will benefit from this campaign.

For your support, students will send regular updates on our activities, pictures of students conducting investigations, and a digital copy of project results.

 

The Impact

I teach my students that, with the digital age, they can have an impact beyond the few blocks around their houses. I also help them understand that education is the most effective tool to break the cycles of drugs, alcohol, and gangs. My discussions with students go beyond the classroom, and we do get very real. I am working to prepare them to be better citizens of the world, to be successful-not defined by money, but by accomplishments, to appreciate the outdoor environment, and to understand we can all have a hand in taking care of the world around us.

When I first started teaching, after 25 years in the business world, I had a student who did exceptionally well on the state test. I told him i was proud of him. He stared at me a couple minutes, then told me no one, not even his parents, have ever said they were proud of him. After moving on to high school, many of my students come back to visit, and tell me I am the reason they stayed in school. Even so, I want to push these students to even higher levels. With your support, I can do this!

Other Ways You Can Help

SoI understand not everyone can contribute to this project, but please tell your friends about it. Email me at Michael.sanderson@fwisd.org, and I will send you updates just for spreading word of our project. I want my students to receive recognition for their efforts.

story:
MSSL Shade Structure Fundraiser

Why We need your help!

Cool shaded playgrounds, protected from the sun with shade structures, allow children to play outdoors longer. Our school is raising money, to buy shade structures for our playground so that children can enjoy more playtime outdoors.

Too much sun causes UV (ultraviolet) radiation exposure to your skin and can cause skin cancer. Become involved and raise funds for shade structures, so that children may enjoy a safe and healthy school environment.

The early brutal Texas heat this summer has convinced us of the need to install a large shade over the north playground to allow the children more outside playing time while being protected from the sun. 

Benefits of a Shade Structure

Montessori School of Sugar Land is launching this new health promoting fundraiser for shade structures to protect our students from harmful UV rays of the sun. This shade structure is to be installed over the playground making it possible to play longer and maximize use of the climber at the school. Most schools desire to install shade structures to protect their children, but up until now this has proven to be a challenge as limited resources have to be utilized elsewhere.

Sun safety Practice

Montessori School of Sugar Land spearheads our community as a beacon of light in sun safety practices. Fundraising for shade is a responsible, health promoting initiative that will change the next generation of youth to be more sun safe and skin cancer conscious. According to statistics from the American Cancer Society, 1 out of every 5 children in the United States today will grow up to have some form of skin cancer. However, 90% of skin cancers are preventable by staying safe under shade outdoors. With these alarming facts, it is no wonder that school districts and communities have become passionate at providing shade for their schools to protect their children from the harsh UV rays of the sun.
story_txt:
MSSL Shade Structure Fundraiser
Why We need your help!
Cool shaded playgrounds, protected from the sun with shade structures, allow children to play outdoors longer. Our school is raising money, to buy shade structures for our playground so that children can enjoy more playtime outdoors.
Too much sun causes UV (ultraviolet) radiation exposure to your skin and can cause skin cancer. Become involved and raise funds for shade structures, so that children may enjoy a safe and healthy school environment.
The early brutal Texas heat this summer has convinced us of the need to install a large shade over the north playground to allow the children more outside playing time while being protected from the sun.

story:
Kids Have Been Waiting

For 4 years we have been bringing laptops to Kenya, so far serving more than 1000 children.

Kids are eager for more!  They want more access, more time, more laptops. Teachers and school administrators also want to be connected, to be part of the world.

Last February we brought 3 laptops to of 8 new sites.  (see map below).

This campaign’s goal is to make sure each site has an initial set of 10 laptops, and 1 BRCK,(high powered modem) and 10 days of our training team.   If we exceed our goal, we plan to purchase the Kenyan government curriculum & One Planet Education games.

The teachers and students want more. Now they understand laptops and access to learning can transform their lives. Time is passing.  These students are waiting for you to reach out and help provide more and better technology for their schools.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Gettting connected to the world and to us. A key piece of this is the Kenya smart invention called 'BRCK' making connectivity possible everywhere.  (http://brck.com).  We plan another round of training and the development of key teams to be part of our regional tech stars. These students will become the leaders for their schools.

  • The new XO 4.0 touch screen costs $225 each.  For each location 4 XO 4.0s and 2 Android tablets
  • One Modem/Router (BRCK) for each site @ $200 each.
  • We will bring to all our classrooms the new Kenyan government's digital curriculum . 
  • We will add the OPEN  (One Planet Education Network  www.oneplaneteducation.com): Google Android & Apple iOS mobile game device-compatible Save Me education game series apps. These tools connect kids in different regions of the world with each other while engaging in cross-cultural discussions, knowledge exchange.  The program provides the opportunity for collaborationon on solutions to real world global problems.
  • If we don't reach our goal, we just will focus on providing key schools with a critical set of hardware and training.

The Impact

A door opens when teachers and children have access to technology.

  • Access to technology  (laptops, tablets, cameras, smart phones, online curriculums, games and apps) is access to knowledge and to the wider world.
  • Children's lives are changed.
  • Unchallenged minds open and the students' eyes light up. 

Risks & Challenges

There is no failure. Even if we meet the goals of this campaign, too many children are still left out. 

  • We will publicize our success, until governments are catch with the demand.
  • We will not just give out laptops, but provide a picture and path the next smart device.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can you make a trip to Kenya, and teach at one of our schools. We will help you get there.

  • Donate to this campaign. These school projects will take off with your support.
  • Start your own 'Connecting Kids' team at your after school program or in your classroom.
  • Keep in touch on Facebook.
  • Start a Connect Kids program in your school (epals@smallsolutionsbigideas.org).

We need your help.  Get your kids involved.

story:
My name is Sandra Castro Solis. I have been accepted to the Human Rights Studies program at Columbia University. I am asking for the financial support of everyone who is willing to assist in funding my two-year education at Columbia. With a Masters in Human Rights Studies I will continue to organize and work to establish policies that aid the community during this human rights violation crisis.  I would like to continue to work with Puente in order to build a sustainable movement that goes beyond defensive strategies to create autonomous spaces and programs that heal and empower our communities for generations to come.  

 

For over five years I have been with the Puente Movement, a grassroots organization that has been at the front lines fighting back against the anti-migrant climate that exists in Arizona.  The struggle in Arizona has taught me a lot about my education and how important it is that our society continues to raise young people of color who can access higher education while remaining deeply rooted in their communities. I have grown up in the struggle, completing my undergraduate tenure while witnessing the human rights violations perpetrated on my community by xenophobic law officials.

 

During my tenure at Arizona State University, I was stripped away from scholarships and even work-study when organizing actions against pro-hate, anti-human rights politicians such as Joe Arpaio, Jan Brewer, and John McCain. This act was one that the university wanted to do for years, I was stripped away from the access to my funding as a way to attempt to silence me and suppress the student activism that was being birthed at ASU. The acts of “intimidation” nor the threats of several deans have not stopped me from both organizing against hate and for dignity and from attaining my education at ASU. Although I was successful in gaining a BA in History and two minors in Women & Gender Studies and Justice Studies, I completed it with the accumulation of student loans.

 

Through my hard work and dedication, I can say I have the privilege of being accepted to Columbia University. Although this is a great accomplishment, I have several difficulties that await me when it comes to funding my education. Columbia University is a private, multi billion-dollar university. Because I am going for an MA (no PhD is offered), there is no way of receiving 100% tuition support from the university. I wish to complete my MA from Columbia with little to no debt because I want to return and continue being a community organizer, a non lucrative but rewarding calling with Puente, the organization that I have been with since day one.

 

Please help contribute to my education at Columbia. Every dollar helps and is greatly appreciated. If you cannot provide financial support right now please think of me in the future and help now by sharing my story to others who can. 

  

Thank you,

Sandra Castro Solis

story:
Who are we?

We are parents. One doctor, a statistician, an artist, a horseback riding instructor. We believe in changing the world  -- one child at a time. We started with our own children. And we introduced them to a group of children a world away who live a different life. Together, they're figuring out how to help each other embrace and make better our shared planet. That's what The Bridge Project is all about.


What will we do?

We are taking a ramshackle school near Accra, Ghana, that's bound together with broken boards, twine, rusty scrap metal and determination. We're covering the holes, nailing on a real roof, and creating a library strong enough to protect its precious donated books. We are rerouting the sewage that once ran through the dirt floor of this special school -- this hallowed dirty ground that has produced doctors and engineers. We are bringing computers, installing electricity and an internet connection so that the children can continue to share in each other's lives. Share friendships. Share teachers. Share music and hope. This is real change. One child at a time.


When?

Constructioin of the library has already begun. Our crew of parents and children will spend the week of Thanksgiving in Ghana, working day and night alongside our Ghanaian friends. Our commitment to the school in ongoing.


We need help!

This project is about more than a small group of American and Ghanaian children. It is intended to be a model. The world will be different. It will be better, when we focus on raising world changers. When children learn to look at the world, and their station in it, through broader eyes, exponential good will result. Please donate to our cause. We need money to buy school building supplies, to connect the electricity, and to install and support the school's internet access. We are taking a Wake Forest University-based film crew with us to document this phase of The Bridge Project in the hope of inspiring others. We also need help in covering the student film crew's basic travel expenses.

story:
It's all about the kids.

This campaign is dedicated to raise enough money for 13 Kitsap County High School students to have Kitsap Racing jerseys for the upcoming 2014 Mountain Bike racing season.

All of the money raised will go directly towards that purchase. No middle man. No passing Go. It will go directly to the purchase of the jerseys, themselves.

Your contribution will help a group of high school kids become part of a team that is a Kitsap County focused racing team. When going to a mountain bike race, where there are up to 400 participants, it is great to be a part of a team that is Kitsap County centric and be able to feel a sense of belonging, and community.

This will allow them to do all of that, while being healthy, active and participating in one of the country's fastest growing sports.

story:
WIMP Crowdfunding Countdown & Pizza Feed

Join us in our last push! We have created new perks so you can purchase event tickets OR you can click "Contribute Now", put in the amount for as many tickets as you want and then select either the $10 ticket perk or the $25 ticket + raffle ticket combo ticket. OR you can pay at the door with cash or credit card.

We'll be giving away prizes, stuffing our faces with pizza, having some beers, and in general just having a Wimpy good time. Bring the whole family!


Ask a person, not a search engine...

is our tag line here at Web & Interactive Media Professionals (or, as we say: WIMP). which is a Sonoma County, California meetup group with big ambitions.

Founded in 2011 by a freelance designer (Melissa) and developer (me, Josh), our goal was simply to find likeminded folks in a place with much less density than San Francisco or Silicon Valley, but not far from them.

But we've since ballooned into a group of over 500 designers, developers, marketers, and other media professionals, and are quickly evolving into a full fledged trade group.

Better yet, we've found that our approach really is unique - one member captured it well when he said WIMP is "a local LinkedIn that doesn't suck." We have a casual approach to professionalism and bring together a variety of skills, creating a rich dialog and solid relationships without the pretense of a networking group.

We've hit a tipping point. We're at a point where we need more than just our co-organizers spare time to really meet our community's needs.

We have hosted nearly 70 meetups and barely any have been recorded, much less livestreamed. And we want to roll out premium memberships to help underwrite our transition from meetup to trade group.

But to do that, we need to be a proper business and we'd like to incorporate as an LLC with B Corp certification, and eventually a benefit corporation, in order to remain accountable to our mission as we grow. That's not cheap.

So we're asking for your help. We're trying to raise $15,000 so we can immediately begin recording and livestreaming our events and begin laying the foundation for our evolution.

Road Map

  • Now - begin incorporation STARTED
  • April 30th - relaunch job board DONE
  • May 10th - define mission statement STARTED
  • May 28th - first recorded meetup with new gear
  • June 25th - first livestreamed meet up
  • June 30th - launch Membership Directory
  • June 30th - launch wiki
  • July 1st - complete incorporation, release founding docs
  • August 1st - begin formal member surveying
  • December 1st - release first report with survey results and analysis including rates, tools, styles, and technologies
  • January 1st, 2015 - release WIMP playbook for new chapters, begin first B Corp Impact Assessment
  • Before January 1st, 2016 - launch first two WIMP satellite chapters

We'll be updating this page a lot with updates, stats, and more. Stay tuned!

See below for FAQ and quotes.

T-shirts awarded to any donation of $100 or more! 

Members Directory

Here is an illustration of what the Members Directory will look like with the breakdown of the different levels.

The Basic Level of Directory Listing is included in the Standard Membership subscription. Each higher level will be an additional monthly or yearly subscription.

The Perks Associated with Each Membership Level:

Basic: $50, $100
Level 3: $150, $250
Level 2: $250, $500
Level 1 (Top Level): $1000 +

The standard pricing structure of each level:

Basic: Included in membership. Membership fees will be $60/year
Level 3: Additional $5/mo or $95/year
Level 2: Additional $15/mo or $195/year
Level 1 (Top Level): $45/mo or $495/year

Now that you have an idea of what's in store, you probably have a better idea of what your investment into the WIMP Indiegogo campaign will get you!

Quotes from WIMPs:

"A local LinkedIn that doesn't suck." - Quinn Supplee

"This was my first meeting. I was very impressed by the quality of information shared. It seemed to be very comfortable for folks to ask questions and share their knowledge. I am glad to have found this group!" - Linda Morrison

"WIMP is an essential asset for us." - Marc Harris

"I am so glad that I found this organization. I already have received many benefits after only two meetings!" - Judy Becker

"It's a wonderful group of trusting souls doing some great work in the world and figuring out how to help each other in the process." - George Moskoff

"Keep up the great work, it's awesome to talk tech with fellow web geeks and I think it fills a niche that was needed locally." - Adam Aragon

Frequently Asked Questions:

Who Are the Wimptators?

We call our leadership team the Wimptators and there are four of us:

  • Cole Geissinger, who rocks production and note taking, is a web developer at Maker Media that specializes in WordPress but has been eying Node.js.
  • Melissa Geissinger, who manages community relationships, is a web designer and photographer that specializes in SmugMug and 1 Day Web Design.
  • Randy Hall, who is an advisor and our go-to guy for video, is a film producer, podcaster, and recovering software engineer.
  • Josh Simmons, our leader, is a community manager at O'Reilly Media as well as a recovering startup CEO and freelance LAMP developer.

What's the Money For?

Two things. First, and most immediately noticeable, we need the money for livestreaming and recording which requires A/V equipment, livestreaming service, T&E for videographers, and, generally, more polish.

Second, and most importantly, we're fundraising to lay a foundation for growth. That includes becoming an LLC, setting up our books, and setting aside some cash for rental costs and our first audit for B Corp certification.

Why a Benefit Corporation? Or, Why Not a Non-profit?

Basically, because our revenue will primarily be from earned income like memberships and job postings rather than donations and grants.

This is our way of building for scale while remaining answerable to our community and its values.

It’s also in the spirit of early adoption. Benefit corporations are a promising new trend in corporate law which provides the best of both the for-profit and non-profit worlds.

How Do Benefit Corporations Work?

Exactly like other corporations. Except for two things: the mission statement has teeth and usually an annual Impact Assessment is, in some states, mandated.

We’ll be incorporating in California, and though we’re not sure what the mandate is here, we’ll be doing that Impact Assessment every year.

Say That Again? What's That Mean in Practice?

Non-profits act like a duck, look like a duck, quack like a duck, and *are* a duck. Benefit corporations act like a duck, but are not, in fact, a duck. Key differences in practice: We can't take tax deductible donations, and whereas non-profits are managed, corporations are owned.

Who Owns WIMP?

Presently WIMP is owned by Melissa and Joshua through a general partnership. Transitioning to benefit corporation doesn't much change that - though we do plan to bring on the rest of the WIMP leadership team as part owners.

Who Will Be Your Officers and Directors?

Our current leadership will largely serve the same roles they do now. All contributing to strategy and operations:

  • Joshua serving an executive capacity
  • Melissa on finance and relations
  • Cole on production

Our board will be made up of:

  • an interdisciplinary mix of OG WIMPs
  • reps from the world of education
  • industry leaders
  • reps from other mission-driven orgs (non-profit or for-profit)
  • and, hopefully, reps from government!

We are hammering out the details and, ultimately, to get everything square we’ll need to engage an attorney.

While our leadership team are leading the charge, our community has always been and will remain to be co-creators. We’ll be soliciting feedback all along the way - in our Facebook group, through our Meetup group, and in-person.

What's Your Mission?

Well, we want to accomplish a lot of things. But we’re trying to boil it down to a few key ingredients, and that’s taking some time. Now that we’re staring incorporation in the face, we’re making that happen *now*.

This is what we know for sure: We want to connect media professionals across disciplines, but as people - that is to say, without the pretense of networking.

We want to become better at our crafts, find friends, get jobs, and share work. We want to keep educators in touch with industry. And we want to help students, the re-skilling, newbies, and the underserved build their careers.

We've done a world of good as an informal group in Sonoma County, and we think we can bring our unique brand of awesome to other locales with their own flavor.

It will be a co-creative process, as mentioned above.

Great. But Seriously, Can We Trust You?

Well, we've been around for three years and have been operated as a fairly opaque general partnership. By moving to benefit corporation we are requiring ourselves to leave a better paper trail as well as subject ourselves to a yearly audit.

That is to say: You should trust us at least as much as you did before.

But we'll do more than just the minimum required of a benefit corporation: We will livestream our board meetings as well as post our founding documents and by-laws online for the world to see.

Cole Geissinger, who rocks production and note taking, is a web developer at Maker Media that specializes in WordPress but has been eying Node.js.
Melissa Geissinger, who manages community relationships, is a web designer and photographer that specializes in SmugMug and 1 Day Web Design.
Randy Hall, who is an advisor and our go-to guy for video, is a film producer, podcaster, and recovering software engineer.
Josh Simmons, our leader, is a community manager at O'Reilly Media as well as a recovering startup CEO and freelance LAMP developer.
What's the Money For?Two things. First, and most immediately noticeable, we need the money for livestreaming and recording which requires A/V equipment, livestreaming service, T&E for videographers, and, generally, more polish.Second, and most importantly, we're fundraising to lay a foundation for growth. That includes becoming an LLC, setting up our books, and setting aside some cash for rental costs and our first audit for B Corp certification.Why a Benefit Corporation? Or, Why Not a Non-profit?Basically, because our revenue will primarily be from earned income like memberships and job postings rather than donations and grants.This is our way of building for scale while remaining answerable to our community and its values.It’s also in the spirit of early adoption. Benefit corporations are a promising new trend in corporate law which provides the best of both the for-profit and non-profit worlds.How Do Benefit Corporations Work?Exactly like other corporations. Except for two things: the mission statement has teeth and usually an annual Impact Assessment is, in some states, mandated.We’ll be incorporating in California, and though we’re not sure what the mandate is here, we’ll be doing that Impact Assessment every year.Say That Again? What's That Mean in Practice?Non-profits act like a duck, look like a duck, quack like a duck, and *are* a duck. Benefit corporations act like a duck, but are not, in fact, a duck. Key differences in practice: We can't take tax deductible donations, and whereas non-profits are managed, corporations are owned.Who Owns WIMP?Presently WIMP is owned by Melissa and Joshua through a general partnership. Transitioning to benefit corporation doesn't much change that - though we do plan to bring on the rest of the WIMP leadership team as part owners.Who Will Be Your Officers and Directors?Our current leadership will largely serve the same roles they do now. All contributing to strategy and operations:
Joshua serving an executive capacity
Melissa on finance and relations
Cole on production
Our board will be made up of:
an interdisciplinary mix of OG WIMPs
reps from the world of education
industry leaders
reps from other mission-driven orgs (non-profit or for-profit)
and, hopefully, reps from government!
We are hammering out the details and, ultimately, to get everything square we’ll need to engage an attorney.While our leadership team are leading the charge, our community has always been and will remain to be co-creators. We’ll be soliciting feedback all along the way - in our Facebook group, through our Meetup group, and in-person.What's Your Mission?Well, we want to accomplish a lot of things. But we’re trying to boil it down to a few key ingredients, and that’s taking some time. Now that we’re staring incorporation in the face, we’re making that happen *now*.This is what we know for sure: We want to connect media professionals across disciplines, but as people - that is to say, without the pretense of networking.We want to become better at our crafts, find friends, get jobs, and share work. We want to keep educators in touch with industry. And we want to help students, the re-skilling, newbies, and the underserved build their careers.We've done a world of good as an informal group in Sonoma County, and we think we can bring our unique brand of awesome to other locales with their own flavor.It will be a co-creative process, as mentioned above.Great. But Seriously, Can We Trust You?Well, we've been around for three years and have been operated as a fairly opaque general partnership. By moving to benefit corporation we are requiring ourselves to leave a better paper trail as well as subject ourselves to a yearly audit.That is to say: You should trust us at least as much as you did before.But we'll do more than just the minimum required of a benefit corporation: We will livestream our board meetings as well as post our founding documents and by-laws online for the world to see.

story:
Summary

One of the steps to expand technical skills to the next level.  Without the software or funding, there is no opportunity to learn. I would like to purchase & learn software in particular to 3D Max and other software license to further expand my skills for the area of 3D graphics and animation with some training opportunities. 

How to Help?

The fund will be needed for:

  • Purchasing up-to-dated software for learning & hands-on experience
  • Software licenses, copyrights
  • Subscription for online video tutorials
  • Educational materials

The Impact

Your help can greatly help to expand software skills and more opportunity for work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
You are funding an entrepreneurial leadership program for young students at high poverty schools in the United States.

One Bead's mission has been to elevate education in East Africa through the sale of recycled glass beads. Now, our six-day program, One Life, will draw upon the entrepreneurial spirit and leadership that has continually guided our successes. 


History

Over the past two years, One Bead has made a visible impact in the lives of over 300 Kenyan students by raising more than $65,000 in bead sales, merchandise, and grants. However, it would be narrow-minded to say these children are the only ones affected. Since graduating from college in May 2013, I am most frequently asked, “What’s next?” Personally, this journey has never been about just one bead. Rather, it is about the letters I receive from representatives telling me how much they appreciate being a part of something bigger than themselves. It is about the pride and confidence we build in students when we return to Kenya. And it is about the lessons I continue to learn from those who mentor me. This entire cycle of leadership all revolves around the simple act of making and selling recycled glass beads. It seems only logical to build upon these strengths. THIS is the answer to “What’s next?” One Life: a leadership program for youth, using the One Bead model.

Strategy

Our business revolves around the mantra that just one bead can make a real difference. Now we take this metaphor further. One Bead will serve as a model that teaches elementary school students how perseverance, self-confidence, and teamwork are all catalysts for change, whether that change is global or individual. 

Our fundraising goal is $20,000. This seed money will allow us to bring our pilot program to four schools in the greater Boston area. Your donation provides essential resources: 

  • a grant for each school of $2,500 that will allow our young leaders to put their newly acquired skills into action, making a difference in their local community
  • facilitating opportunities for local entrepreneurs to speak during the final session of One Life
  • creating global connections for our leaders with students worldwide
  • travel expenses to and from the schools we work with
  • the resources needed to research, assess, and make any changes to the curriculum after the pilot program has been completed
  • pens, pencils, paper and various other supplies needed to teach students how to be a leader
  • compensation for two individuals who are ready to devote more than 50 hours a week to running the One Life curriculum at all four schools in addition to developing the next stages of the program.

Why Now

“It is not nearly enough to teach students how the world is. We must also encourage them to think about how it ought to be.” - Harriger & Ford (1989)

The world is changing at a rapid pace. The Common Core Learning Standards that are taught in public schools challenge students in English Language Arts (ELA), writing, and mathematics. These subjects are emphasized as the fundamental basis of elementary education. In order for students to have the creativity, adaptability, and perseverance to solve the complex problems that our world will be confronted with in the upcoming century, students are going to need more than what the standardized tests evaluate and deem important.

What students learn during the extent of the academic school day is imperative to developing their skills in reading, writing, and math.  However, there are other skills - leadership skills - that are essential for students to practice and learn in order for them to be ethical and contributing members of a future college, organization, business, and community. We will hold our program in an after-school setting to provide an opportunity for students to practice and model what it means to be an ethical leader. This will build on what they are already learning during the day.

The Impact

The inherent flexibility of our curriculum, along with the unique global entrepreneur model of One Bead, allows us to stand alone from similar organizations. Ultimately, the integration of leadership into the elementary school culture will work to build confidence and autonomy among students in preparation for both current and future roles. The end goal is twofold: It is critical for students to be prepared and competitive in their future areas of employment, while also learning how to be contributing and valuable citizens in the community and world in which they live.

The five-year goal is to have this program implemented in more than 100 schools, maximizing the network of youth leaders across the country. 

Below are a few examples of the learning objectives that were taken directly from One Life's leadership curriculum. These objectives speak to the curricular and instructional goals of the program:

  • Our leaders will explore and discuss the theme of 'leading self.' 
  • Our leaders will be able to describe five leadership strengths that they possess and to reflect on how they can use these strengths when working in groups.
  • Our leaders will craft their “I Believe” statement, in which they will be challenged to write what they believe is true about leadership.
  • Our leaders will explore the theme of 'leading others' through group discussions about the complex relationship between leaders and followers. 
  • After being introduced to the idea of an action plan, the group will collectively brainstorm how they can positively impact their community.
  • Our leaders will take the leadership skills we have been exploring and discussing and put them into practice by participating in a service project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate, but still want to be a part of the movement?

  • Share this site on your Facebook page.
  • Like us on facebook: http://www.facebook.com/OneBead
  • Share our story with your friends and family.
  • Visit our website and apply to be a representative at your school: www.onebead.org
  • E-mail us to come speak at YOUR school! onebeadproject@gmail.com

story:
Our Story

CredoMatrix is an investigative analysis web site that tracks opinions of political organizations on critical issues facing society, providing political competitive analysis by showing opinions from the left, right and middle to help individuals do their own research and make their own opinions. The CredoMatrix vision is to do well as a business by doing good for society.

The Impact

While budgets are slashed for newspapers and other media channels, CredoMatrix is creating a platform for comparative analysis of important issues available over the internet. CredoMatrix introduces new analysis tools for individuals to become better informed and enlightened about the politics surrounding critical issues.  CredoMatrix has an elegant dashboard for navigation with access to in depth, investigative analysis journalism and Interactive multimedia. CredoMatrix addresses controversial issues facing society: the mission is to be provocative and engaging – controversial and viral.


What We Need & What You Get

We need $50K to launch beta; this will pay programmers, journalists and legal fees.  We will open the site to the general public as soon as the next stage of development work is completed. During Beta it will be a work in progress as content is completed, and the site is improved.


We will take pledges from $5 to $2500. For twenty five dollars, you get a CredoMatrix T Shirt. The other pledge levels are described on our IndieGoGo page.  Your pledge demonstrates there is demand for what we’re doing.


Other Ways You Can Help

Contribute via PayPal if possible. 
Please forward information to your news and political junkie friends, post links on Facebook, Tweet, and eMail.  Pledge now,  wear our T-shirt and tell your friends about CredoMatrix - Science.  Any size donation helps, and demonstrates there is demand for this type of investigative, analytical journalism.

story:
My youngest son is Autistic and we find it hard to travel because hotel rooms do not offer appropriate safety features for our son. We are not the only family that deals with this issue and I want to make it easier for families with children on the spectrum to enjoy the same quality of vacation as an average family.

My goal is to create an opt-in program for hotels whereby they can purchase kits that will help them retrofit several rooms in their hotels so that they can offer "Autism Aware Accommodations" to their guests.

There will be two sizes of kit offered to hotels (for small rooms and larger rooms) and they will be adjustable depending on the room requirements. The kit will include:

- Higher Door Locks 

- Switch Plate Covers

- Door Beepers

- Patio Door Locks

- T.V Wall Mounts  

To begin the first fifty hotels will be offered these kits at no cost to get the program running along with suggestions to make their facilities more Autism Aware.

The actual cost of the kit will be roughly 200.00 (at retail) with the hope that in future the cost will be reduced by purchasing the products in bulk. The more we raise, the more kits we can offer!

Once a hotel has opted in and the room(s) have been retrofitted they will be given a sticker for the door to declare that they offer Autism Aware Accommodations as well as a pamphlet for each retrofitted room explaining the features for guests.

In the end families with children on the spectrum will feel safer about going on vacation and will seek out hotels that offer these accommodations. 

While we cannot offer any large perks for this campaign donors will have their name on the pamphlet for a specific number of kits sold. And large donors will be able to donate a kit in someone's name.


Even if you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Autism affects everyone.
  • On average Autism affects 1 in 88 children.
  • Please use the share tools to spread awareness about this campaign!

story:
Hello Dear Friends! :)

  • JCI London is part of JCI (Junior Chamber International), also known as Junior Chamber of Commerce for London. It is a dynamic network for young professionals in London in their 20's and 30's. JCI's mission is to provide development opportunities that empower young people to create positive change.

  • JCI London to Tamale' is a Campaign aiming at fundraising for 1,000 malaria nets and deliver those nets to Tamale, in Northern Ghana, in January 2014.
  • Contributors will help us purchase 1,000 malaria nets that will allow saving 2,000 lives and in particular kids's lives.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • To buy 1,000 nets, we need £7,000. We have already fundraised for £3,000
  • Here are the unique perks we offer you:
    • PDF certificate of your contribution to the project
    • Personal note from a team member
    • Handwritten note from a team member
    • Invitation for our Indiegogo Finale party on 29 
    • Google hangout with the Team
    • And some more to come!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, the funds raised will still go to purchase malaria nets that we will bring in Tamale in January 2014. Our aim is to deliver 1,000, but if we have less we will still deliver the amount of nets that we have. If we fundraise for more, than our target, we will simply purchase and deliver more nets!

 

 

The Impact

  • By getting involved in this project, you really make a difference and become part of the global effort initiated by the United Nations under MDG number 6c to eradicate major diseases including malaria worldwide.
  • You will in fact help saving 2,000 lives, of which many children's lives. And what is best in life that saving or improving the lives of others?

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • Make a click to like our Facebook page: www.facebook.com/London2GhanaJCI

 

Thank you very much for taking the time to read our pledge. Together, we are confident we can help save lives and make this world a better place! :) 

JCI London to Tamale NBN Team

 

DETAILS OF THE PERKS:

. For £25 you receive the book 'Go for Success' from Success Coach Nilesh Waghchoude:

story:
Support the children of Kenya to take action against corruption! 

Your money will achieve something incredibly powerful. It will empower young Kenyans to learn how to build a better Kenya. An educated and empowered youth, who act with integrity, can break the cycles of corruption in Kenya. Don't believe it's possible? Then donate and see. 

Kenya loses 3.5 billion US dollars (300 billion shillings) to corruption, every year. Children are part of the movement standing up and saying No. 

No. More. Corruption.

"Supported by Transparency International Kenya, there are now 27 Integrity Clubs in our schools throughout the country, supporting 2500 children in our fight against corruption!

These clubs need financial support to stay open and to connect with each other. Please help us! "


How much is Needed? 

450,000 Kenya shillings or 5,000 US dollars will directly support two primary school clubs in Nairobi (BuruBuru 1 Primary School and Ayany Primary School) with their running costs, and it will support the development of an online platform and a newspaper to connect all of the clubs across the country. 

"At Integrity Clubs in our schools, we learn about corruption, and how we can stop it. Through crafts, music ,art, essays, poetry, games and discussion, we share our experiences of corruption and learn that there is a different way of doing things. We learn how to resist corruption and how to build a better Kenya.

This way, we can speak to and connect with other children who also care. We show other children that it is not hopeless, and that we are not alone!

We hope you see why this is valuable for us and for the future of Kenya! Thank You! With Best Wishes, from the Primary School Children of BuruBuru1 and Ayany! "

More about the Campaign from the people supporting us...

Hello, we're Transparency International Kenya - a not-for-profit organization founded in 1999 in Kenya with the aim of developing a transparent and corruption free society through good governance and social justice initiatives.

We're an autonomous member of the global anti-corruption movement. We provide a platform for sharing knowledge and experience, develop strategies to respond to regionally distinct patterns of corruption and initiate advocacy campaigns at both the regional and sub-regional level.  

Young people are the future of our country. In order to empower them to be positive change-makers, we helped to establish Integrity Clubs in schools across Kenya, to give children in those schools a platform to engage on integrity and anti-corruption issues. 

100% of the contribution that will be received will be used to finance the activities of the two Integrity clubs, supporting Kenyan Children to resist corruption. Such activities include: education and communication materials designed for children, an online learning platform, a club delegation to parliament to present a petition to parliament, and an art and essay fair, to mention but a few. 

The Children of Kenya are tired of corruption. Please donate to show them that you agree. By keeping open their integrity clubs, you can help them to say No to corruption and secure lasting change towards a better future for Kenya.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Please help us share this campaign with your friends by using the social media share buttons in this page.

Follow Transparency International Kenya on Facebook and Twitter
